title: Prokaryotic Cell Structure
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Introduction to prokaryotic cell structure including nucleoid region, cell wall, ribosomes, and flagella. Students learn to distinguish prokaryotic from eukaryotic cells using key structural criteria.
learningIntentions: Students can identify the key structural features of prokaryotic cells (nucleoid region, cell wall, ribosomes, flagelia).
Students can distinguish between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells using four basic criteria (presence/absence of nucleus, ribosome size, cell wall composition, DNA shape).
Students can explain why antibiotics that target prokaryotic ribosomes do not affect human cells.

syllabusLinks.module: Module 1: Cells as the Basis of Life
syllabusLinks.inquiryQuestion: IQ1: What distinguishes one cell from another?

successCriteria: I can draw and label a prokaryotic cell showing the nucleoid region, cell wall, and 70S ribosomes.
I can state three ways prokaryotic cells differ from eukaryotic cells.
I can explain the significance of the nucleoid region having no membrane.

engagementHook.title: The Invisible Army
engagementHook.content: Show an image of E. coli next to a human hair. Explain that one bacterial cell can become 17 million in 12 hours. Ask: 'This cell has no nucleus, no mitochondria, and no complex internal structures. How does it survive and reproduce so successfully? And why can penicillin kill it but not harm your cells?'

keyConcepts.definition: Simple cells with no membrane-bound organelles. Examples include bacteria and archaea. Size range 1–10 µm.
Area where the circular DNA is located. Not surrounded by a membrane (unlike the nucleus in eukaryotes).
Smaller than eukaryotic ribosomes (site of protein synthesis). Target of antibiotics like tetracycline.
Provides structure and protection. Made of peptidoglycan in bacteria (different from cellulose in plants or chitin in fungi).
Small circular pieces of DNA separate from the main chromosome, often carrying antibiotic resistance genes.
Used for movement. Lack the 9+2 microtubule arrangement found in eukaryotic flagella.

misconceptions.correction: Students confuse 'nucleoid' with 'nucleus' due to similar names. Emphasise 'nucleoid = NO membrane' and 'nucleus = HAS membrane.' Use analogy: nucleoid is like a pile of string in a room; nucleus is that string inside a sealed bag.
Students associate bacteria only with disease. Discuss gut bacteria (microbiome) and decomposition. Only a small percentage cause disease.
Students think simple structure means simple function. Explain metabolic diversity (nitrogen fixation, extreme environment survival).

contentSections.title: Basic Prokaryotic Structure
contentSections.content: Simple diagram showing cell wall, plasma membrane, nucleoid (circular DNA), ribosomes (small dots), flagellum, and capsule. No internal organelles shown.
keyPoints: Nucleoid contains circular DNA; no membrane-bound nucleus
contentSections.example: Escherichia coli in the human intestine—some strains helpful, some harmful.
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: Why can't we see ribosomes under a light microscope? (Too small—need electron microscope.)

contentSections.title: Antibiotics and Ribosomes
contentSections.content: Antibiotics like tetracycline bind to 70S ribosomes and stop protein synthesis in bacteria. Human cells have 80S ribosomes (different shape), so the antibiotic does not affect them. This is called selective toxicity.
contentSections.example: Treating bacterial infections (strep throat) with antibiotics without harming human cells. MRSA (antibiotic-resistant bacteria) evolves when bacteria develop ways to block the antibiotic.
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: Why don't antibiotics kill human cells when you take them for a throat infection?

multipleChoice.question: Which structure is found in prokaryotic cells but absent from eukaryotic cells?
multipleChoice.rationale: Both cell types have ribosomes and DNA. Only eukaryotes have membrane-bound nucleus. Peptidoglycan cell wall is specific to bacteria (prokaryotes).

multipleChoice.question: The main difference between the nucleoid of a bacterium and the nucleus of an animal cell is that the nucleoid:
options: Is not surrounded by a membrane
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Is not surrounded by a membrane
multipleChoice.rationale: Students often think 'nucleoid' means 'small nucleus' with membrane. The key difference is nucleoid has NO membrane, while nucleus HAS a double membrane.

multipleChoice.question: Antibiotics such as tetracycline are effective against bacteria because they:
multipleChoice.rationale: Antibiotics exploit the difference between 70S (bacterial) and 80S (human) ribosomes. Penicillin destroys cell walls; tetracycline targets ribosomes.

shortAnswer.question: Distinguish between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells with reference to the presence of a nucleus and the structure of ribosomes. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Prokaryotes have nucleoid region (no membrane) vs eukaryotes have membrane-bound nucleus
1 mark: Prokaryotes have 70S ribosomes vs eukaryotes have 80S ribosomes
shortAnswer.commonError: Stating prokaryotes have 'no DNA' or confusing 70S/80S sizes.

shortAnswer.question: Explain why bacterial cells can be killed by antibiotics that target their ribosomes, while human cells are not affected. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Bacterial ribosomes are 70S (small) while human ribosomes are 80S (different structure)
1 mark: Antibiotics can bind to/block 70S ribosomes but not 80S ribosomes (selective toxicity)
shortAnswer.commonError: Saying 'bacteria are weaker' rather than explaining structural difference.

definitions: Prokaryotic cells have no membrane-bound nucleus (have nucleoid region instead).
Prokaryotic DNA is circular; eukaryotic DNA is linear.
Prokaryotic ribosomes are 70S (smaller than eukaryotic 80S ribosomes).
Cell walls contain peptidoglycan (not cellulose like plants).
keyPoints: Nucleoid region = NO membrane, contains circular DNA
70S ribosomes are smaller than 80S and targeted by antibiotics
Flagella lack the 9+2 arrangement found in eukaryotes
diagrams: Labelled diagram of prokaryotic cell showing nucleoid, cell wall, ribosomes, flagellum

shortAnswer: Prokaryotic cells have a nucleoid region (not surrounded by a membrane) whereas eukaryotic cells have a membrane-bound nucleus. Prokaryotes have 70S ribosomes which are smaller than the 80S ribosomes found in eukaryotes.

Bacterial cells have 70S ribosomes which have a different structure from the 80S ribosomes in human cells. Antibiotics like tetracycline can bind to the 70S ribosomes and block protein synthesis in bacteria, but they cannot bind to the larger 80S ribosomes in human cells, so protein synthesis in human cells is not affected. This is called selective toxicity.
